awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research; The Role Of Function In Traditional Weapon Design
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to understand the role that function plays in traditional weaponry design. It will investigate the evolution of Ice Age stone tool weaponry, dated to13,500 to 12,500 years, used by hunter-gatherers in the colonization of North America. The weapons, stone point tips attached to spears and called "Clovis points" by archaeologists, were flintknapped into specimens with parallel to slightly convex sides, a concave base, and flake-removal scars; termed "flutes." These flutes occur on one or both faces and on average extend from the base to about a third of the way to the tip. These points are found across North America, having spread widely and rapidly at an unprecedented rate. During this expansion over space, across time, and in different environments the size and shape of Clovis points changed significantly. Archaeologists know that cultural drift contributed to this variation, but is it possible that this single source could alone generate so much variation so quickly? Or are multiple sources, for example cultural drift + functional changes, necessary to so rapidly give rise to such variety? If functional differences are found among different forms of Clovis points, it follows that Clovis people in different times and places may have chosen specific attributes to provide them with a selective functional advantage. The project will contribute to the overall understanding of how and why weapons evolve among small, mobile, isolated groups of humans ; a fundamental anthropological question of broad archaeological and ethnographic relevance, as well as to many situations in the present day. Furthermore, since the peopling of the Americas was part of the broader late Pleistocene global dispersal of human out of Africa, this project will ultimately advance the understanding of the behavioral and technological adaptations that determined how our species came to so successfully colonize the planet. 

The investigators will examine whether different sizes and shapes of Clovis points possess any functional advantages or disadvantages. Through a series of realistic hunting-related experiments in conjunction with a series of controlled engineering experiments, the researchers will determine the prey penetration-ability, aerodynamics, durability, fracture mechanics, and cutting-efficiency of replica Clovis points of varying forms.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to better understand why the weaponry of the First Stone Age Americans, the Clovis culture, evolved. As people bearing Clovis technology traveled across North America ca. 13,500-13,000 years ago, their stone hunting weaponry changed in size and shape. Several studies have already shown that random processes (e.g. drift) contributed to this technological evolution. Our research wished to understand whether tool function also contributed to the evolution of Clovis weaponry. In other words, were the people who used Clovis technology selecting aspects of their weaponry to function in particular ways in different environments or specific situations?

            To answer this question, we first needed to understand whether different forms of Clovis weaponry functioned differently in unique performance tasks. This is because if different sizes and shapes of Clovis points functioned similarly, then there would have been no particular functional weaponry features that prehistoric people would have selected. Thus, to understand how different Clovis weaponry forms functioned, we conducted, and are conducting, an extensive experimental archaeological analysis that quantitatively tests how different forms performed in different tasks. Seven replica Clovis stone weaponry forms were created and then used in controlled laboratory tests.

            We focused on five performance tasks: projectile penetration, projectile durability, knife cutting effectiveness, knife edge wear, and projectile aerodynamics. Of these, we have completed the analysis of the first three: projectile penetration, durability, knife cutting effectiveness (this last one is currently under review for publication). Data for knife edge wear and projectile aerodynamics are still being collected.

            However, we can already conclusively state that different Clovis stone weaponry forms do indeed function differently:

(1)  Specific sizes and shapes penetrate a hunting target at substantially and significantly different depths than do other sizes and shapes.

(2)  Specific sizes and shapes are substantially and significantly more durable than other sizes and shapes.

(3)  Specific sizes and shapes are substantially and significantly more effective at knife cutting through different media than are other sizes and shapes.

Although data are still being collected, we predict that different forms of Clovis weaponry will also yield different edge wear and aerodynamics.

            Unexpectedly, our experimental tests have also resulted in several interesting comparisons to the archaeological record, particularly with regard to the debate of whether people bearing Clovis technology regularly hunted proboscideans. Our experimental tests also resulted in a new methodological advance involving the use of aluminum in projectile tests.

            Understanding that different Clovis point weaponry forms function differently is consistent with the hypothesis that prehistoric selection of functional attributes contributed to Clovis weaponry evolution. However, it is not enough to robustly support that hypothesis. To do that, once all of our experimental data are collected and analyzed, we will conduct an analysis of the archaeological, geographic, and paleoenvironmental records to assess whether there is co-variance between Clovis weaponry function and location. If there is, then the hypothesis that human selection of functional attributes contributed to Clovis weaponry evolution will be supported. If there is no evidence of co-variance, the hypothesis will not be supported.

            Over the course of this project, in addition to analyzing and publishing research, we gave dozens of tours of the Kent State University Experimental Archaeology Laboratory, public talks, and flintknapping demonstrations to the public in Ohio and beyond.
